intro: Phacelia parviflora var. hirsuta, commonly known as the hairy phacelia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and leaves. The plant produces small, blue to violet flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed areas. Its botanical features make it a valuable plant for pollinators and a candidate for ecological restoration projects.
